Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research LTREB: Understanding the strength, duration, and stability of connectivity effects on community diversity
Award.AbstractNarration:
Habitat loss is the greatest cause of biodiversity loss, as it isolates small patches of habitat along with the populations in these fragments. This project examines landscape connectivity, which is the inverse of fragmentation, and the degree to which corridors among fragments facilitate the movement of organisms and thus alleviate the effects of fragmentation. Although habitat connectivity is considered to be fundamental to the maintenance of species diversity, there is remarkably little empirical evidence documenting the effects of corridors. The investigators will extend an ongoing experiment explicitly designed to test the effects of habitat connectivity. Results to date show that species diversity increases when fragments are connected by corridors, but the question remains whether these responses are short-term or persistent. The project will generate long-term data to resolve the mechanisms underlying the relationship between connectivity, diversity, and time, and to determine whether connectivity effects are long-lasting or transient.


This experiment provides a direct link to conservation by manipulating connectivity through landscape corridors. Strategies to reconnect landscapes through landscape corridors have dominated land acquisitions in conservation. Results of this project will provide some of the first evidence for land managers of the value of landscape connections for protecting biological diversity. The project will develop a solutions-oriented workshop with scientists and land managers to catalyze the translation of science to practical long-term land conservation in the southeastern United States study region. A website dedicated to bridging the science and practice of conservation corridors will contribute to these efforts. Both graduate and undergraduate students will be engaged in and trained through participation in the research, continuing a successful collaboration with the US Forest Service to train and mentor women and students from underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
People have converted many forest, grassland, and wetland landscapes to farm fields and urban areas. This has caused loss of habitat area available to plants and animals. In addition to reduced area, the natural habitat that remains has been chopped into smaller and smaller fragments, for example in the form of city parks or woodlots that are widely dispersed across landscapes. How do we conserve biodiversity and functioning ecosystems in these landscapes?

One leading strategy is to build connections between the small fragments that remain. When natural areas are fragmented, farm fields or urban areas may create barriers to plants or animals that may want to move to other places. If they venture out of their native habitats, they are more likely to perish. So-called landscape corridors serve as highways for plants and animals to move safely between fragments. If corridors work as intended, more movement across the landscape will increase population sizes and biodiversity in connected landscapes. However, it is unknown whether corridors work in this way.

For the past twenty years, we have measured the impacts of corridors on the diversity of plant species using a large-scale, whole-ecosystem experiment. This experiment contains eight landscapes and, in each landscape, 100x100m fragments are either connected by a corridor or unconnected and isolated from each other. This has been possible because of a long-term collaboration with the U.S. Forest Service and the U.S. Department of Energy at the Savannah River Site in South Carolina to create and maintain controlled and replicated experimental landscapes that test how corridors work.

The major Intellectual Merit outcome of this grant was to show that connecting fragments by corridors increased the number of plant species over time by increasing colonization and reducing extinction rates. We found this for 239 species of plants recorded within our fragmentation experiment over 18 years, including the five years of this grant. Like compound interest in a bank, the number of species has increased at a constant rate each year, resulting in many more species in habitat fragments connected by a corridor than in those that are unconnected by corridors and isolated from each other. After almost two decades, there are 24 more species of plants in fragments connected by a corridor than in unconnected fragments. The reason for this was that, each year, plant species are more likely to newly colonize fragments connected by corridors and, once there, are less likely to go extinct in corridor-connected fragments.

We were very surprised by the continual positive impact of corridors over the entire 18 years. We expected that the benefits might plateau, or even decrease, but we did not expect them to continue to accrue. After nearly 20 years, the positive increase in plant diversity in connected fragments still continues.

This project supported five main types of Broader Impacts. First, we have informed conservation of our focal longleaf pine ecosystem, which is imperiled and part of a world biodiversity hotspot. By doing so in a well-controlled, large experiment, we have shown that corridors increase conservation of fragmented landscapes broadly. Conservation investments have tradeoffs, and our research suggests that the time to start connecting habitat is now, as it will pay off down the road (like investing money in the bank with an annual, positive interest rate). Second, we trained students, including 6 graduate students and 13 undergraduates. Third, we enhanced and contributed to a website that bridges the science and practice of conservation corridors (conservationcorridor.org). During this grant, we created over 200 posts and attracted close to 4,000 users per month through this website. Fourth, this grant supported the long-term stability of our unique long-term, large-scale landscape experiment, including the infrastructure needed to maintain the experiment within managed pine plantation forests maintained by the USDA Forest Service. Fifth, during this grant, we made a substantial amount of data publically available, including our main plant diversity data set, as well as 13 previously collected datasets from our experiment.
